Title: How to get accurate code coverage report using gcovr for MSYS2 MINGW64 Clang project?
Body:
I try to use gcovr tool to obtain code coverage of a C++ project built on Windows using MSYS2 MINGW64's Clang toolchain.
I've decided to use such setup to mimic how the project is built on the CI system.
The project consists of a test executable E (it uses GoogleTest framework) and two static libraries, L1 and L2, having the following dependencies: L1 -> L2; L1, L2 -> E.
It is build using CMake system.
When building for code coverage, at the very beginning of the whole process I append to all targets the following compiler flags (CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS): -g --coverage -fPIC -O0 -fno-elide-constructors
Then, I generate code coverage report using the following command:
-- C:/msys64/mingw64/bin/gcovr.exe --html index.html --html-details -r <PROJECT_ROOT> --object-directory=<BUILD_DIR> --gcov-executable=llvm-cov gcov --merge-mode-functions=merge-use-line-min --exclude-unreachable-branches --exclude-function-lines --exclude-lines-by-pattern '^\s*\}?\s*$'
The first problem I've encountered is that for at least one source file some functions were found on multiple lines in the same file - what makes no sense to me, as e.g. gcovr reported one of such functions to start in L183 and L185, whereas it actually starts in L185 and L183 contains the closing brace of totally different function. I have no clue why I got this error, but managed to bypass it by using --merge-mode-functions=merge-use-line-min flag.
However, the resulting report is garbage. In particular, numerous empty lines as well as lines containing only comments/closing braces are marked as "not hit" what makes the output rather not useful.
Note that I've used --exclude-lines-by-pattern '^\s*\}?\s*$' flag, but for some reason it did not filter out the mentioned problematic lines.

What should I do to make the results more accurate? Use different compiler/linker flags? A different coverage tool?
A different toolchain is not so feasible solution, as then I would have to constantly rebuild the whole project to switch between e.g. Clang <-> GCC.
I've tried to add -Xclang -fprofile-instrument=clang compiler flags to all build targets, but then the build process was stuck at linking my test executable E (or the process was slowed down, that I assumed it became staled; instead of completing let's say in 10-20 seconds, it did not finished even after a few minutes).

#---------------------------------------------
# this is a comment
#---------------------------------------------

I wanted to write a VIM snippet (using UltiSnips) that pads the comment box up until column number 80 (or better until vims colorcolumn). It should take the indentation level into account and always fill the dashes up until column 80.
I have a working snippet present that looks like this
snippet #
#`!p snip.rv = '-' * (80 - vim.current.window.cursor[1])`
# $1
#`!p snip.rv = '-' * (80 - vim.current.window.cursor[1])`
$0
endsnippet

I think I need a pyhton or VIM variable that holdes the lines column from which I can subtract 80. But I can't find anything that works for this case.
Edit:
I've found one possible solution to avoid the moving dashes in the template by checking snip.c By checking for emptyness I can make sure that interpolation is done only once.
snippet #
#`!p if snip.c == "": snip.rv = '-' * (80 - vim.current.window.cursor[1])`
# $1
#`!p if snip.c == "": snip.rv = '-' * (80 - vim.current.window.cursor[1])`
$0

Title: Correctly tear down process when using pytest with multiprocessing
Body:
I am working on a package that includes a server with the corresponding client.
I was thinking that I could save a lot of effort mocking all the interactions and just write some test cases that test both sides at the same time.
So I wrote a fixture that would yield a multiprocessing.Process instance inside which the server is running.
When the tests are done I tear down the process using process.terminate(). Unfortunately there is another "orphaned" process that I can't seem to get a handle on.
How do I remove the other process or how do I avoid starting it in the first place?
If you know of a way of doing this with a different library than multiprocessing I am totally open to it.
To reproduce the problem I used the code from how-to-make-a-simple-python-rest-server-and-client to create a simple Rest Server/Client Pair.

import asyncio
import logging
import multiprocessing as mp

import pytest
import pytest_asyncio
import requests
from flask import Flask, jsonify


def server():
    app = Flask(__name__)

    tasks = [
        {
            "id": 1,
            "title": "Buy groceries",
            "description": "Milk, Cheese, Pizza, Fruit, Tylenol",
            "done": False,
        },
        {
            "id": 2,
            "title": "Learn Python",
            "description": "Need to find a good Python tutorial on the web",
            "done": False,
        },
    ]

    @app.route("/todo/api/v1.0/tasks", methods=["GET"])
    def get_tasks():
        return jsonify({"tasks": tasks})

    app.run()


class TestMultiprocessingTester:

    @pytest.fixture(scope="class")
    def server_process(self):
        server_process = mp.Process(target=server)
        server_process.start()
        yield server_process
        server_process.terminate()
        if server_process.is_alive():
            server_process.kill()
        logging.getLogger("Process").warning("shut down server process")

    @pytest.mark.asyncio
    async def test_client(self, server_process: mp.Process):
        await asyncio.sleep(10)
        url = "http://localhost:5000/todo/api/v1.0/tasks"
        response = requests.get(url)
        assert response.status_code == 200
        assert response.json()["tasks"][0]["done"] is False

Title: is getenv_s not part of cstdlib?
Body:

However, when I include <cstdlib>, I do not have std::getenv_s, only getenv_s (global namespace).
cppreference has the following note:

As with all bounds-checked functions, getenv_s is only guaranteed to be available if __STDC_LIB_EXT1__ is defined by the implementation and if the user defines __STDC_WANT_LIB_EXT1__ to the integer constant 1 before including <stdlib.h>.

Even when I define __STDC_WANT_LIB_EXT1__ as 1, My compiler (MSVC C++23) does not find the std::getenv_s function.

Isn't <cstdlib> supposed to bring every symbol of <stdlib.h> into the std namespace?
